Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase II Noyce project is preparing science and mathematics teachers, knowledgeable in their content areas, familiar with standards based education and prepared to meet the challenges of teaching in high needs schools by: 1) recruiting highly qualified individuals into science and mathematics teaching career pathways; 2) preparing and presenting course materials that address the challenges and rewards of working in high needs schools; 3) providing early teaching experiences in these schools; and 4) supporting the science and mathematics teachers in their induction years through the assistance of former Noyce scholars currently working in similar schools. It builds on a previous Noyce Phase I award (0531856) which awarded forty-two scholarships and four stipends to prospective science and mathematics teachers who committed to teach in high needs schools. This project expands and enhances Stony Brook's commitment to working with high needs schools on Long Island and in New York City.

Eight two-year scholarships are being awarded to attract talented undergraduate science and mathematics majors to enter the teaching workforce. Twenty-five, one-year scholarships are being awarded to STEM professionals undertaking teacher certification studies through a Masters in Teaching program. Eight two-year stipends are being awarded to graduates of the program working in high needs schools, who have committed to contributing to Stoney Brook's teacher education programs and to in service professional development activities. School districts involved include Brentwood, Central Islip, New York City, and William Floyd. Other contributing entities include the New York State Urban Teacher Education Center (SUTEC) and Stony Brook's recently created Center for Science and Mathematics Education (CESAME)

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this proposal is that it profits from and builds upon the success of prior projects in order to advance knowledge of teacher preparation, with respect to early teaching experiences and novice teacher induction practices, and how these affect teachers in high needs schools. The monitoring, evaluation and dissemination of the Phase I and Phase II outcomes are also being expanded. They are being evaluated with respect to their success in recruiting, preparing and retaining teachers in the high needs schools of the region. Longitudinal data is also being collected in order to provide data concerning the long-term program features that contribute to effective science and mathematics teacher development.

Broader Impact: The project's broader impacts include: 1) improvement in the quality and quantity of mathematics and science teachers for high needs schools; 2) building of new models for the recruitment, preparation, and retention of mathematics and science teachers to meet teacher shortages, and 3) dissemination of findings that have the potential to advance knowledge in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building on the success of a previous Noyce I grant, the Stony Brook University Phase II Noyce award sought to advance knowledge of teacher preparation, particularly with respect to early teaching experiences and novice teacher induction practices and how these affect STEM teachers in high-need schools. The project's broader impacts included: 1) improving in the quality and quantity of mathematics and science teachers for high-need schools in the region; 2) the building of new models for the recruitment, preparation, and retention of mathematics and science teachers to meet the teacher shortages, and 3) the dissemination of findings from the activities undertaken in the project to a wider audience in the field locally, regionally and nationally.

Specific goals for the project with their outcomes were to:

a)     Recruit highly qualified individuals into science and mathematics teaching careers and prepare effective, competent science and mathematics teachers, knowledgeable in their content areas. The project recruited and funded 40 mathematics and science teachers (out of 41 requested awards). These included 23 one-year scholarships, 8 two-year undergraduate scholarships and 9 two-year stipends for in-service high-need school STEM teachers.

All Noyce scholarship students (n=31) had GPAs of 3.0 or above and all had or were in the process of obtaining degrees in their content area; all passed the state certification content specialty test at the first attempt. The project had specifically targeted the enrollment of physics, chemistry and mathematics pre-service teachers and 20 of the awardees were in these fields. Notably, the program recruited 8 pre-service physics teachers, which was integral in the SBU Science teacher preparation program receiving PhysTEC 5+ Awards for physics teacher production for 4 consecutive years during the Noyce II Award period. The program was also selected as one of the eight thriving Physics Teacher Education Programs in a recent PhysTEC study.

b)    Provide a host of early teaching experiences to prepare the awardees for student teaching and the early years of their teaching careers. The SBU STEM teacher preparation programs initiated a range of teaching experiences including requiring all our candidates to complete field experiences in high-need schools. We increased our requirement to 50 hours observation in high-need schools to be completed before student teaching. Additionally, Noyce scholars were required to complete a semester of student teaching in a high-need school.

c)     Support the science and mathematics pre-service teachers and also teachers in their induction years, through the assistance of more senior Noyce awardees. As part of the Noyce award we recruited 9 highly experienced high-need STEM teachers to work with all of our pre-service teachers in our on-campus courses. These experienced teachers spent 4 semesters working with our students and served as co-teachers for the Methods 1 and 2 courses and the Student Teacher Seminar. They brought contemporary educational practices to the student teachers, particularly with regard to technology, recent approaches to NGSS and New York State curricular requirements, classroom management, home contacts, and school/district procedures. They expanded the teaching/learning discourse by bringing their own experiences to the discussions. They assisted the program administrators, as needed, to rework ideas and processes to best prepare the pre-service teachers to work with students in high-need schools.

The project disseminated its findings through several national and regional conference presentations and is working on manuscripts for eventual publication in science education journals.
